body: Question, do we really need to support parameter collection from client side? As we are providing e2e tracing, server side is not enough?

> Question, do we really need to support parameter collection from client side? As we are providing e2e tracing, server side is not enough?

Maybe when accessing external services(that are impossible to be instrumented by SkyWalking)?
if not server is not supported by skywalking, such as s3?
OK, maybe.

@wu-sheng @kezhenxu94 I have some problems and need your help. MQTT Because the protocol header is fixed, it is impossible to pass the contextcarrier header, and the consumer cannot get it. As a result, the whole call chain producer and consumer are disconnected. I have come up with a solution. I put the contextcarrier header in the mqtt payload, and then get the set from the consumer to the carrieritem. However, there is a problem. If the user can install the If our mqtt plugin is installed, but the consumer side is another service. If the mqtt plugin is not installed, the message will be changed by string instead of the message delivered by the user. Is there any other way to implement the header transmission of contextcarrier.

解决了

```xml
    <appender name="logstash" class="net.logstash.logback.appender.LogstashTcpSocketAppender">
        <destination>${logging.logstash}</destination>
        <encoder charset="UTF-8" class="net.logstash.logback.encoder.LoggingEventCompositeJsonEncoder">
            <providers>
                <provider class="org.apache.skywalking.apm.toolkit.log.logback.v1.x.logstash.TraceIdJsonProvider"/>
                <timestamp>
                    <timeZone>UTC</timeZone>
                </timestamp>
                <pattern>
                    <pattern>
                        {
                        "level": "%level",
                        "serviceName": "${spring.application.name:-}",
                        "serviceId": "${spring.application.instance-id:-}",
                        "pid": "${PID:-}",
                        "tid": "%tid",
                        "thread": "%thread",
                        "class": "%logger{1.}:%L",
                        "message": "%message",
                        "stackTrace": "%exception{10}"
                        }
                    </pattern>
                </pattern>
            </providers>
        </encoder>
    </appender>

    <appender name="ASYNC" class="ch.qos.logback.classic.AsyncAppender">
        <discardingThreshold>0</discardingThreshold>
        <queueSize>256</queueSize>
        <appender-ref ref="logstash"/>
    </appender>
```

We need a deep discussion about this.

> If this is happening, this plugin should never exist in the official plugin, even it is optional. The reason for this is, in the real production environment, it is nearly impossible to make sure the plugin has been installed on both sides always. Also, this makes the agent's features, including uninstallable and harmless, are gone.

There are currently 2 schemes:
One is an optional plug-in that supports the entire mqtt tracing function, but the premise is that the agent must be installed on both sides
Another solution is that the user is not required to install mqtt-plugin on both sides, but the tracing of producer and consumer is disconnected

Is there a better way to solve this problem?
 
Now, the Mqtt.md file is described as follows：
## Support mqtt3.X
Here is an optional plugin `apm-mqtt-3.x-plugin`

## Introduce
The Mqtt header cannot be expanded, and the Agent access requires attention
### Notice:
- Agent consumer and producer must be installed at the same time!!!
- Agent installation sequence, consumer first, producer second, is very important!!!
- Copy `apm-mqtt-3.x-plugin.jar` to `agent/plugins`, restarting the `agent` can effect the plugin.
